trans-unit.source: The Standard .NET Event Pattern
trans-unit.target: The Standard .NET Event Pattern

trans-unit.source: The Standard .NET Event Pattern
trans-unit.target: The Standard .NET Event Pattern

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: The Standard .NET Event Pattern
trans-unit.target: The Standard .NET Event Pattern

trans-unit.source: Previous
trans-unit.target: Previous

trans-unit.source: .NET events generally follow a few known patterns.
trans-unit.target: .NET events generally follow a few known patterns.

trans-unit.source: Standardizing on these patterns means that developers can leverage knowledge of those standard patterns, which can be applied to any .NET event program.
trans-unit.target: Standardizing on these patterns means that developers can leverage knowledge of those standard patterns, which can be applied to any .NET event program.

trans-unit.source: Let's go through these standard patterns so you will have all the knowledge you need to create standard event sources, and subscribe and process standard events in your code.
trans-unit.target: Let's go through these standard patterns so you will have all the knowledge you need to create standard event sources, and subscribe and process standard events in your code.

trans-unit.source: Event Delegate Signatures
trans-unit.target: Event Delegate Signatures

trans-unit.source: The standard signature for a .NET event delegate is:
trans-unit.target: The standard signature for a .NET event delegate is:

trans-unit.source: The return type is void.
trans-unit.target: The return type is void.

trans-unit.source: Events are based on delegates and are multicast delegates.
trans-unit.target: Events are based on delegates and are multicast delegates.

trans-unit.source: That supports multiple subscribers for any event source.
trans-unit.target: That supports multiple subscribers for any event source.

trans-unit.source: The single return value from a method doesn't scale to multiple event subscribers.
trans-unit.target: The single return value from a method doesn't scale to multiple event subscribers.

trans-unit.source: Which return value does the event source see after raising an event?
trans-unit.target: Which return value does the event source see after raising an event?

trans-unit.source: Later in this article you'll see how to create event protocols that support event subscribers that report information to the event source.
trans-unit.target: Later in this article you'll see how to create event protocols that support event subscribers that report information to the event source.

trans-unit.source: The argument list contains two arguments: the sender, and the event arguments.
trans-unit.target: The argument list contains two arguments: the sender, and the event arguments.

trans-unit.source: The compile time type of `sender` is `System.Object`, even though you likely know a more derived type that would always be correct.
trans-unit.target: The compile time type of `sender` is `System.Object`, even though you likely know a more derived type that would always be correct.

trans-unit.source: By convention, use `object`.
trans-unit.target: By convention, use `object`.

trans-unit.source: The second argument has typically been a type that is derived from `System.EventArgs`.
trans-unit.target: The second argument has typically been a type that is derived from `System.EventArgs`.

trans-unit.source: (You'll see in the [next section](modern-events.md) that this convention is no longer enforced.) If your event type does not need any additional arguments, you will still provide both arguments.
trans-unit.target: (You'll see in the [next section](modern-events.md) that this convention is no longer enforced.) If your event type does not need any additional arguments, you will still provide both arguments.

trans-unit.source: There is a special value, `EventArgs.Empty` that you should use to denote that your event does not contain any additional information.
trans-unit.target: There is a special value, `EventArgs.Empty` that you should use to denote that your event does not contain any additional information.

trans-unit.source: Let's build a class that lists files in a directory, or any of its subdirectories that follow a pattern.
trans-unit.target: Let's build a class that lists files in a directory, or any of its subdirectories that follow a pattern.

trans-unit.source: This component raises an event for each file found that matches the pattern.
trans-unit.target: This component raises an event for each file found that matches the pattern.

trans-unit.source: Using an event model provides some design advantages.
trans-unit.target: Using an event model provides some design advantages.

trans-unit.source: You can create multiple event listeners that perform different actions when a sought file is found.
trans-unit.target: You can create multiple event listeners that perform different actions when a sought file is found.

trans-unit.source: Combining the different listeners can create more robust algorithms.
trans-unit.target: Combining the different listeners can create more robust algorithms.

trans-unit.source: Here is the initial event argument declaration for finding a sought file:
trans-unit.target: Here is the initial event argument declaration for finding a sought file:

trans-unit.source: Even though this type looks like a small, data-only type, you should follow the convention and make it a reference (`class`) type.
trans-unit.target: Even though this type looks like a small, data-only type, you should follow the convention and make it a reference (`class`) type.

trans-unit.source: That means the argument object will be passed by reference, and any updates to the data will be viewed by all subscribers.
trans-unit.target: That means the argument object will be passed by reference, and any updates to the data will be viewed by all subscribers.

trans-unit.source: The first version is an immutable object.
trans-unit.target: The first version is an immutable object.

trans-unit.source: You should prefer to make the properties in your event argument type immutable.
trans-unit.target: You should prefer to make the properties in your event argument type immutable.

trans-unit.source: That way, one subscriber cannot change the values before another subscriber sees them.
trans-unit.target: That way, one subscriber cannot change the values before another subscriber sees them.

trans-unit.source: (There are exceptions to this, as you'll see below.)
trans-unit.target: (There are exceptions to this, as you'll see below.)

trans-unit.source: Next, we need to create the event declaration in the FileSearcher class.
trans-unit.target: Next, we need to create the event declaration in the FileSearcher class.

trans-unit.source: Leveraging the `EventHandler<T>` type means that you don't need to create yet another type definition.
trans-unit.target: Leveraging the `EventHandler<T>` type means that you don't need to create yet another type definition.

trans-unit.source: You simply use a generic specialization.
trans-unit.target: You simply use a generic specialization.

trans-unit.source: Let's fill out the FileSearcher class to search for files that match a pattern, and raise the correct event when a match is discovered.
trans-unit.target: Let's fill out the FileSearcher class to search for files that match a pattern, and raise the correct event when a match is discovered.

trans-unit.source: Definining and Raising Field-Like Events
trans-unit.target: Definining and Raising Field-Like Events

trans-unit.source: The simplest way to add an event to your class is to declare that event as a public field, as in the above example:
trans-unit.target: The simplest way to add an event to your class is to declare that event as a public field, as in the above example:

trans-unit.source: This looks like it's declaring a public field, which would appear to be bad object oriented practice.
trans-unit.target: This looks like it's declaring a public field, which would appear to be bad object oriented practice.

trans-unit.source: You want to protect data access through properties, or methods.
trans-unit.target: You want to protect data access through properties, or methods.

trans-unit.source: While this make look like a bad practice, the code generated by the compiler does create wrappers so that the event objects can only be accessed in safe ways.
trans-unit.target: While this make look like a bad practice, the code generated by the compiler does create wrappers so that the event objects can only be accessed in safe ways.

trans-unit.source: The only operations available on a field-like event are add handler:
trans-unit.target: The only operations available on a field-like event are add handler:

trans-unit.source: and remove handler:
trans-unit.target: and remove handler:

trans-unit.source: Note that there's a local variable for the handler.
trans-unit.target: Note that there's a local variable for the handler.

trans-unit.source: If you used the body of the lambda, the remove would not work correctly.
trans-unit.target: If you used the body of the lambda, the remove would not work correctly.

trans-unit.source: It would be a different instance of the delegate, and silently do nothing.
trans-unit.target: It would be a different instance of the delegate, and silently do nothing.

trans-unit.source: Code outside the class cannot raise the event, nor can it perform any other operations.
trans-unit.target: Code outside the class cannot raise the event, nor can it perform any other operations.

trans-unit.source: Returning Values from Event Subscribers
trans-unit.target: Returning Values from Event Subscribers

trans-unit.source: Your simple version is working fine.
trans-unit.target: Your simple version is working fine.

trans-unit.source: Let's add another feature: Cancellation.
trans-unit.target: Let's add another feature: Cancellation.

trans-unit.source: When you raise the found event, listeners should be able to stop further processing, if this file is that last one sought.
trans-unit.target: When you raise the found event, listeners should be able to stop further processing, if this file is that last one sought.

trans-unit.source: The event handlers do not return a value, so you need to communicate that in another way.
trans-unit.target: The event handlers do not return a value, so you need to communicate that in another way.

trans-unit.source: The standard event pattern uses the EventArgs object to include fields that event subscribers can use to communicate cancel.
trans-unit.target: The standard event pattern uses the EventArgs object to include fields that event subscribers can use to communicate cancel.

trans-unit.source: There are two different patterns that could be used, based on the semantics of the Cancel contract.
trans-unit.target: There are two different patterns that could be used, based on the semantics of the Cancel contract.

trans-unit.source: In both cases, you'll add a boolean field to the EventArguments for the found file event.
trans-unit.target: In both cases, you'll add a boolean field to the EventArguments for the found file event.

trans-unit.source: One pattern would allow any one subscriber to cancel the operation.
trans-unit.target: One pattern would allow any one subscriber to cancel the operation.

trans-unit.source: For this pattern, the new field is initialized to `false`.
trans-unit.target: For this pattern, the new field is initialized to `false`.

trans-unit.source: Any subscriber can change it to `true`.
trans-unit.target: Any subscriber can change it to `true`.

trans-unit.source: After all subscribers have seen the event raised, the FileSearcher component examines the boolean value and takes action.
trans-unit.target: After all subscribers have seen the event raised, the FileSearcher component examines the boolean value and takes action.

trans-unit.source: The second pattern would only cancel the operation if all subscribers wanted the operation cancelled.
trans-unit.target: The second pattern would only cancel the operation if all subscribers wanted the operation cancelled.

trans-unit.source: In this pattern, the new field is initialized to indicate the operation should cancel, and any subscriber could change it to indicate the operation should continue.
trans-unit.target: In this pattern, the new field is initialized to indicate the operation should cancel, and any subscriber could change it to indicate the operation should continue.

trans-unit.source: After all subscribers have seen the event raised, the FileSearcher component examines the boolean and takes action.
trans-unit.target: After all subscribers have seen the event raised, the FileSearcher component examines the boolean and takes action.

trans-unit.source: There is one extra step in this pattern: the component needs to know if any subscribers have seen the event.
trans-unit.target: There is one extra step in this pattern: the component needs to know if any subscribers have seen the event.

trans-unit.source: If there are no subscribers, the field would indicate a cancel incorrectly.
trans-unit.target: If there are no subscribers, the field would indicate a cancel incorrectly.

trans-unit.source: Let's implement the first version for this sample.
trans-unit.target: Let's implement the first version for this sample.

trans-unit.source: You need to add a boolean field to the FileFoundEventArgs type:
trans-unit.target: You need to add a boolean field to the FileFoundEventArgs type:

trans-unit.source: This new Field should be initialized to false, so you don't cancel for no reason.
trans-unit.target: This new Field should be initialized to false, so you don't cancel for no reason.

trans-unit.source: That is the default value for a boolean field, so that happens automatically.
trans-unit.target: That is the default value for a boolean field, so that happens automatically.

trans-unit.source: The only other change to the component is to check the flag after raising the event to see if any of the subscribers have requested a cancellation:
trans-unit.target: The only other change to the component is to check the flag after raising the event to see if any of the subscribers have requested a cancellation:

trans-unit.source: One advantage of this pattern is that it isn't a breaking change.
trans-unit.target: One advantage of this pattern is that it isn't a breaking change.

trans-unit.source: None of the subscribers requested a cancel before, and they still are not.
trans-unit.target: None of the subscribers requested a cancel before, and they still are not.

trans-unit.source: None of the subscriber code needs updating unless they want to support the new cancel protocol.
trans-unit.target: None of the subscriber code needs updating unless they want to support the new cancel protocol.

trans-unit.source: It's very loosely coupled.
trans-unit.target: It's very loosely coupled.

trans-unit.source: Let's update the subscriber so that it requests a cancellation once it finds the first executable:
trans-unit.target: Let's update the subscriber so that it requests a cancellation once it finds the first executable:

trans-unit.source: Adding Another Event Declaration
trans-unit.target: Adding Another Event Declaration

trans-unit.source: Let's add one more feature, and demonstrate other language idioms for events.
trans-unit.target: Let's add one more feature, and demonstrate other language idioms for events.

trans-unit.source: Let's add an overload of the `Search()` method that traverses all subdirectories in search of files.
trans-unit.target: Let's add an overload of the `Search()` method that traverses all subdirectories in search of files.

trans-unit.source: This could get to be a lengthy operation in a directory with many sub-directories.
trans-unit.target: This could get to be a lengthy operation in a directory with many sub-directories.

trans-unit.source: Let's add an event that gets raised when each new directory search begins.
trans-unit.target: Let's add an event that gets raised when each new directory search begins.

trans-unit.source: This enables subscribers to track progress, and update the user as to progress.
trans-unit.target: This enables subscribers to track progress, and update the user as to progress.

trans-unit.source: All the samples you've created so far are public.
trans-unit.target: All the samples you've created so far are public.

trans-unit.source: Let's make this one an internal event.
trans-unit.target: Let's make this one an internal event.

trans-unit.source: That means you can also make the types used for the arguments internal as well.
trans-unit.target: That means you can also make the types used for the arguments internal as well.

trans-unit.source: You'll start by creating the new EventArgs derived class for reporting the new directory and progress.
trans-unit.target: You'll start by creating the new EventArgs derived class for reporting the new directory and progress.

trans-unit.source: Again, you can follow the recommendations to make an immutable reference type for the event arguments.
trans-unit.target: Again, you can follow the recommendations to make an immutable reference type for the event arguments.

trans-unit.source: Next, define the event.
trans-unit.target: Next, define the event.

trans-unit.source: This time, you'll use a different syntax.
trans-unit.target: This time, you'll use a different syntax.

trans-unit.source: In addition to using the field syntax, you can explicitly create the property, with add and remove handlers.
trans-unit.target: In addition to using the field syntax, you can explicitly create the property, with add and remove handlers.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, you won't need extra code in those handlers in this project, but this shows how you would create them.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, you won't need extra code in those handlers in this project, but this shows how you would create them.

trans-unit.source: In may ways, the code you write here mirrors the code the compiler generates for the field event definitions you've seen earlier.
trans-unit.target: In may ways, the code you write here mirrors the code the compiler generates for the field event definitions you've seen earlier.

trans-unit.source: You create the event using syntax very similar to that used for [properties](properties.md).
trans-unit.target: You create the event using syntax very similar to that used for [properties](properties.md).

trans-unit.source: Notice that the handlers have different names: `add` and `remove`.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the handlers have different names: `add` and `remove`.

trans-unit.source: These are called to subscribe to the event, or unsubscribe from the event.
trans-unit.target: These are called to subscribe to the event, or unsubscribe from the event.

trans-unit.source: Notice that you also must declare a private backing field to store the event variable.
trans-unit.target: Notice that you also must declare a private backing field to store the event variable.

trans-unit.source: It is initialized to null.
trans-unit.target: It is initialized to null.

trans-unit.source: Next, let's add the overload of the Search() method that traverses subdirectories and raises both events.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's add the overload of the Search() method that traverses subdirectories and raises both events.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to accomplish this is to use a default argument to specify that you want to search all directories:
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to accomplish this is to use a default argument to specify that you want to search all directories:

trans-unit.source: At this point, you can run the application calling the overload for searching all sub-directories.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you can run the application calling the overload for searching all sub-directories.

trans-unit.source: There are no subscribers on the new `OnChangeDirectory` event, but usingh the `?.Invoke()` idiom ensures that this works correctly.
trans-unit.target: There are no subscribers on the new `OnChangeDirectory` event, but usingh the `?.Invoke()` idiom ensures that this works correctly.

trans-unit.source: Let's add a handler to write a line that shows the progress in the console window.
trans-unit.target: Let's add a handler to write a line that shows the progress in the console window.

trans-unit.source: You've seen patterns that are followed throughout the .NET ecosystem.
trans-unit.target: You've seen patterns that are followed throughout the .NET ecosystem.

trans-unit.source: By learning these patterns and conventions, you'll be writing idiomatic C# and .NET quickly.
trans-unit.target: By learning these patterns and conventions, you'll be writing idiomatic C# and .NET quickly.

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll see some changes in these patterns in the most recent release of .NET.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll see some changes in these patterns in the most recent release of .NET.
